Hugh Hefner, the controversial editor-publisher of Playboy
magazine, will participate in a
YMCA-sponsored panel discussion of "The Playboy Philosophy
in America" May 2 at, 8:30 p.m.
in Shrivel. Hall. Other members
of the panel will be Dr. Mary
Calderone and Dr. William Hamilton, who, along with Hefner,
will discuss modern American
morals.
With the advent of the Playboy Philosophy in December, 1963
Hefner has conducted a concerted attack against what he feels
is the anachronistic moral codes
by which Americans live today.
His remarks have made him a
prominent figure in American
society, and they have become
the object of more press and academic comment than any editorial feature in the Playboy magazine's history.

Public Service
The New Baltimore Morning
Herald will function primarily
as a public service including
major emphasis on local news,
sports, legal notices, entertainment, finance, real estate, obituaries and society news. In publishing the Herald, the corporation does not break union rules
and follows a successful precedent set in Detroit. Cleveland
and New York. There is no truth
to the rumor that the Baltimore
Sun has subsidised The Herald to
prolong the strike, a story that
has circulated widely on the
Guild picket lines.
While the staff of the new
paper will include many members of the Editorial Board oif
The Johns Hopkins News-Letter
it has no official connection with
the University. Because finandai
support of the Herald would entail jeopardizing the University's
tax status as a non-profit organization, the Hopkins Administration has encouraged and offered
moral backing to the fledgling
daily.

which the
terregnum
hitherto junior Dooks have

The News-Letter ;tends firmly in the outstreached palm
of the lean and hungry
youths who have turned out
all semblence of age and experience in favor of enthusiasm.

Freedom?
But is there any meaningful worth to our academic
freedom? Do we gain anything from the obviously inadequate advising system, from the distinction between
majors and concentrates, from the lack of administrative organization on the undergraduate level?
Our academic freedom really seems to he the result of neglect and lack of interest, and there does not
sem to be any way in which we as undergraduates profit
form it.
Should we not be willing to sacrifice some autonomy for closer supervision over our academic activities, creation of a dean of undergraduate affairs, with
additional lower level administrators and a professional
staff of advisors, and the abolition of the concentration?
The implied choke is clear: do we prefer academic neglect or a eommittment on the part of the
university to take a closer interest in our academic
lives?
If asked to state what they felt was the greatest
strength of this university, many undergraduates, after
long and torturous thought, would say "the freedom."
What they usually mean is that, unlike an undergraduate at Harvard or Swarthmore, et. al., the Hopkins
man is permitted to leave the dormitories if he wishes
after his freshman year and live in a fraternity or an
apartment.
Whether this freedom is the result of design or
neglect on the part of the administration is not particularly meaningful as long as there is no change.
What the Undergraduate Long Range Planning
Committee is now considering is the effect of change
on this freedom, first in the context of co-education,
second in the area of curriculum.
In this light they have developed a distinction between social and academic freedom. Social freedom,
living in apartments or fraternities, seems to he highly
regarded by most undergraduates and should not be
lightly forsaken.
A SPRING TRIBUTE TO GOUCHER
Too long the Hopkins man has lived.
assailed by norks and often snibbed
by fantasies of Portami. (Puzzled, puss?
It's just the plural of Portamus.)
But in this quandary, he is saved
by dreams of Goucher girls.
their countenance so duly played
with troom beneath their golden curls.
Oh girls of Goucher, shining bright!
I think of you most every night,
and of the gentleness and grace
which you belie with grimfuld face;
and of the incapacity
that can't be yours with such loquacity
and of your sprightly feminosity,
anhancing primsical precocity.
And of your sparkling wit,
and of your firmly rounded personality.
But do not think me very naughty
to praise the goodies you embody.
Oh girls of Goucher, shining bright/
the Portamus can never harm me
when with such wonders you do charm
said neither can the nork, nor dark:
I think of you and want to snark!

TESTS,AND HOW THEY GREW
Just the other night I was saying to the little woman,"Do'
you think the importance of tests in American colleges is
being overemphasized?". (Incidentally, the little woman is
not, as you might think, my wife. My wife is far from a little woman. She is, in fact, nearly seven feet high and mantled with rippling muscles. She is a full-blooded Ogallala
Sioux and holds the world's shot put record. The little
woman I referred to is someone we found crouching under
the sofa when we moved into our apartment back in 1928,
and there she has remained ever since. She never speaks
except to make a kind of guttural clicking sound when she
is hungry. To tell you the truth, she's not too much fun to
have around the house,but:with my wife away at track meets
most of the time, at least it gives me someone to talk to.)
But I digress. "Do you think the importance of tests in
American colleges is being overemphasized?" I said the
other night to the little woman, and then I said, "Yes,
Max, I do think the importance of tests in American colleges is being overemphasized." (As I explained, the little
woman does not speak, so when we have conversations, I
am forced to do both parts.)
But I digress. To get back to tests—sure, they're important, but let's not allow them to get too important. There
are, after all, many talents which simply can't be measured
by quizzes. Is it right to penalize a gifted student whose
gifts don't happen to fall into an academic category? Like,
lor instance, Finster Sigafoos?

Finster, a freshman at the Wyoming College of Belles
Lettres and Fingerprint Identification, has never passed a
single test; yet all who know him agree he is studded with
talent like a ham with cloves. He can, for example, sleep
standing up. He can do a perfect imitation of a scarlet tanager. (I don't mean just the bird calls; I mean he can fly
south in the winter.) He can pick up BB's with his toes. He
can say "toy boat" three times fast. He can build a rude
telephone out of 100 yards of string and two empty Personna Stainless Steel Razor Blade packages. (This last accomplishment is the one Finster is proudest of—not building
the telephone but emptying the Personna packs. To empty
a Personna pack is not easily accomplished, believe you me,
not if you're a person who likes to get full value out of his
razor blades. And full value is just what Personnas deliver.
They last and last and keep on lasting; luxury shave follows
luxury shave in numbers that make the mind boggle. Why
don't you see for yourself? Personnas are now available in
two varieties: a brand-new stainless steel injector blade for
users of injector razors—and the familiar double-edge stainless steel blade so dear to the hearth and kind to the kissers
of so many happy Americans, blades so smooth-shaving, so
long-lasting that the Personna Co. makes the following
guarantee: If you don't agree Personna gives you more luxury shaves than Beep-Beep or any other brand you might
name, Personna will buy you a pack of whatever kind you
think is better.)
But I digress. Back to Finster Sigafoos— artist, humanist,
philosopher, and freshman since 1939. Will the world ever
benefit from Finster's great gifts? Alas, no. He is in college
to stay.
But even more tragic for mankind is the ease of Clare de
Loon. Clare, a classmate of Finster's, had no talent, no
gifts, no brains, no personality. All she had was a knack for
taking tests. She would cram like mad before a test, always
get a perfect score, and then promptly forget everything
she had learned. Naturally, she graduated with highest
honors and degrees by the dozen, but the sad fact is that
she left college no more educated and no more prepared to
cope with the world than she was when she entered. Today,
a broken woman,she crouches under my sofa.

The fourth-place varsity tennis team figures to improve its
1-4 record when it crosses racquets with Washington College
tomorrow afternoon.
The netmen, under Coach Tom
McDermott, picked up their only
win to date against Western
Maryland but looked a great deal
better than they had for two
seasons.
In this 7-1 victory, top man
Joe Sorrow won 6-1, 6-0; Mark
Ellenbogen won 7-5, 6-2; Bob
Childers went 4-6,6-0,8-6; John
Lowe won 6-4, 6-4; and Rick
Jelovsek defeated his man 6-1,
6-3.
Win Doubles
Two of the Jay doubles combinations won, while the number
three doubles match was called
because of darkness.
Bob Childers put in the best
effort of the day. Losing the
first set, he lumbered back to
shut his opponent out in the second. Childers pushed on in the
tight third set, eventually taking
it 8-6.
Against Haverford on Parent's
Day, Hopkins was defeated 61/2-

2. The long meet was tense
5 1/
nevertheless. Sorrow seemed to
have trouble with his softer-playing opponent. Only after
twenty-seven games, 6-3 and 108, did Sorrow take Hopkins' only
singles match.
Give Exhibition

Lowe also gave the spectator.)
an interesting match. After taking the first set 6-4, the div)
slipped up on the second 3-6
And then a long third set began
Lasting close to an hour. As
darkness rolled in, the match
with the final set at 8-8 was
declared a tie.
In the return match with
Loyola this Tuesday, the varsity
will seek to avenge its earlier
6-3 loss to the Greyhounds.
The freshmen tennis team
brought its record to 1-1 with an
easy 7-2 victory over Baltimore
Polytechnic.

Kit Battenfield (6-2 and 6-3).
George Miller (6-1 and 6-3)

Frosh Batsmen Close Season;
Meet Frederick, Glen Burnie
The freshman baseball squad
ends its short season with two
home games this weekend, one
today at 3:30 against Frederick
High School, the other tomorrow
afternoon at 1:30 against Glen
Burnie High School.
The contingent brings a 1-3
record into today's encounter,
but the statistics are not a good
indication of the team's quality
and potential, according to Coach
Sam Case. Well-balanced, the
team features consistent hiters,
good fielders and excellent pitchers.
Lack Practice
"We played our first game before we had our first" practice",
commented Case. "The squad is
a good, hard-working one but
has been hurt by the weather."
This past week. for example,
practice was called off, and varsity games took up the field
on Tuesday and Thursday. Thus

the Jays had only Wednesday to
get ready for today's game.
The bulk of the hitting has
been supplied by Dave Thomas,
Webster Gray, Jim Ca111, Pete
Martindale, and Mike Shaw.
The mainstay of the pitching
staff is Erie Javel, who has
pitched 18 of the team's 30 innings so far. In one effort, he
fanned 11 batters in 6 and 2 innings. Rounding out the pitching are Rob Snyder, Dan Frey,
and Wally Siggers.
Lists Roster
The rest of Case's lineup is as
follows: Charles Allegrone, outfield; James Buchanan, first
bage; Aldrich Davis, second base;
James Easter. first base; Dave
Komocki, shortstop; Bill Mitchell,
outeld. Also listed are Tom Mobley, catcher; Ron Smith, outfield; and William Thorn, outfield.
Last season the freshman diamonders played only two games,
losing both.

in a hurry.

4 tiny rollers. They make sure only
whiskers disappear. Not skin.
348 cutting edges take care of that •
fast disappearing act. Honed from
surgical high-carbon steel, these cutters
start sharp, stay sharp.
Add to this the sideburn trimmer:
a straightedge tucked under the
head case that gives you a neat,
finishing touch.
Then there's the cordless feature.
Works on rechargeable energy cells.
(Also works with a cord, if you forget
to recharge.) So you can shave where
and when the itch hits you. Frees you
from sockets and wet sinks.
So, you can easily see why it costs
a bit more. Even if you can't add or
handle a slide rule.

Lacrosse History

Pitching Collapses
Even pitching, the Jays' one
usual source of strength, collapsed. About the only competent
performance was Frank Soriano's
five-inning relief stint against
Ursinus. Arnie Michelson, Merlin
Batt, and Soriano himself were
thoroughly combed in starting
roles.
Part of the hill staff's problems can be traced to the past
Iveek's schedule, which saw the
Jays play three games in four
days.
This hampered any attempt
by Coach Gary Barrette to man
an effective bull pen and made
it necessary for the starters
(with the exception of Batt) to
go the route, even if hit hard.

Syracuse
By JIM MANGIARDO
With an attack that is still
hobbling and a defense which has
proven that it can do the job
when called upon, the varsity
lacrosse team travels north tomorrow to challenge an ambitious Syracuse club.
Syracuse, which usually schedules just teams from the Ohio
and New England areas, has
played the Jays only four times.
The last contest was in 1963
when Hopkins edged the visitors
10-7.
Returning from that team
which gave the Jays this battle
are Duncan Crowther, Tom Kennedy, Barry Loucks, and Art
Markusen.
Nominated All-America
Crowther is Syracuse's nomination for All-America this year.
The midfielder scored two
goals and had an assist in the
1963 game. Kennedy, another
midfielder, also had a goal in
the fray.
Completing the starting midfield for the Orangemen is
Loucks. Markusen will start on
defense. The man to watch on
the Syracuse attack is Al Smoral,
an underclassman.
"Syracuse will play the same
sort of game that Yale played,"
Coach Bob Scott predicted.
"They are hard hitting and will
do a lot of personal dogging."
Look Ahead
"It will be very easy for the
team to think ahead to Navy as
we thought of Army in the
Washington College game. But
we will have to remember that
we have to play real well to win.
We just can not lower ourselves
to their level as we have done
consistently this year against ou
minor competition."
After his brief talk about his
opposition this weekend, the
coach went on to discuss his
team's play against Army. Hopkins upset the Cadets by pouring in three goals in the final
period to break a 3-3 tie.

Newsletter Correspondent
The varsity lacrosse team put
a check on Army's highly touted
attack Saturday as it scrambled
to a 6-3 victory, Hopkins' seventh straight.
The encounter was the Jays'
best defensive effort of the campaign. Their defensive trio—
Hank Kaestner, Mike Oidick, and
Joe Blattner—stayed in action
the entire fray and didn't commit a single foul to boot.
Kaestner covered the Cadets'
All-American attackman Toni
Sheckells, while Oidick was on
Ray Enners. Starting in place of
injured Denny Townsend. Blattner guarded third-string AllAmerican Bill Ritch.
Army Scores First
Scrapping characterized most
of the play. At ten minutes in
the first period, the Cadets drew
first blood when second-midfielder Jim Tillman took Enners'
feed and scored.
A
minute
later, Hopkins
bruised Army's defense with a
marker of its own—on a pass
from Skip Darrell to Stan Fine.
When Jerry Pfeifer, playing on
a sore leg, assisted Chip Giardina at eight minutes in the second period. Coach Bob Scott's
charges went ahead.
Tie Game
Sheckells retaliated, however,
by scooping up a loose ball and
slamming it into the goal unassisted.
In the third period, Al Huston.
who played both crease attack
and second midfield, took a pass
from Herb Better and converted
It into a goal. Again Sheckells
tied it up for Army, picking up
another ground ball and scoring.

Public Service
The New Baltimore Morning
Herald will function primarily
as a public service including
major emphasis on local news,
sports, legal notices, entertainment, finance, real estate, obituaries and society news. In publishing the Herald, the corporation does not break union rules
and follows a successful precedent set in Detroit. Cleveland
and New York. There is no truth
to the rumor that the Baltimore
Sun has subsidised The Herald to
prolong the strike, a story that
has circulated widely on the
Guild picket lines.
While the staff of the new
paper will include many members of the Editorial Board oif

it has no official connection with
the University. Because finandai
support of the Herald would entail jeopardizing the University's
tax status as a non-profit organization, the Hopkins Administration has encouraged and offered

daily.

Freedom?
But is there any meaningful worth to our academic
freedom? Do we gain anything from the obviously inadequate advising system, from the distinction between
majors and concentrates, from the lack of administrative organization on the undergraduate level?
Our academic freedom really seems to he the result of neglect and lack of interest, and there does not
sem to be any way in which we as undergraduates profit
form it.
Should we not be willing to sacrifice some autonomy for closer supervision over our academic activities, creation of a dean of undergraduate affairs, with
additional lower level administrators and a professional
staff of advisors, and the abolition of the concentration?
The implied choke is clear: do we prefer academic neglect or a eommittment on the part of the
university to take a closer interest in our academic
lives?
If asked to state what they felt was the greatest
strength of this university, many undergraduates, after
long and torturous thought, would say "the freedom."
What they usually mean is that, unlike an undergraduate at Harvard or Swarthmore, et. al., the Hopkins
man is permitted to leave the dormitories if he wishes
after his freshman year and live in a fraternity or an
apartment.
Whether this freedom is the result of design or
neglect on the part of the administration is not particularly meaningful as long as there is no change.
What the Undergraduate Long Range Planning
Committee is now considering is the effect of change
on this freedom, first in the context of co-education,
second in the area of curriculum.
In this light they have developed a distinction between social and academic freedom. Social freedom,
living in apartments or fraternities, seems to he highly
regarded by most undergraduates and should not be
lightly forsaken.

TESTS,AND HOW THEY GREW
Just the other night I was saying to the little woman,"Do'
you think the importance of tests in American colleges is
being overemphasized?". (Incidentally, the little woman is
not, as you might think, my wife. My wife is far from a little woman. She is, in fact, nearly seven feet high and mantled with rippling muscles. She is a full-blooded Ogallala
Sioux and holds the world's shot put record. The little
woman I referred to is someone we found crouching under
the sofa when we moved into our apartment back in 1928,
and there she has remained ever since. She never speaks
except to make a kind of guttural clicking sound when she
is hungry. To tell you the truth, she's not too much fun to
have around the house,but:with my wife away at track meets
most of the time, at least it gives me someone to talk to.)
But I digress. "Do you think the importance of tests in
American colleges is being overemphasized?" I said the
other night to the little woman, and then I said, "Yes,
Max, I do think the importance of tests in American colleges is being overemphasized." (As I explained, the little
woman does not speak, so when we have conversations, I
am forced to do both parts.)
But I digress. To get back to tests—sure, they're important, but let's not allow them to get too important. There
are, after all, many talents which simply can't be measured
by quizzes. Is it right to penalize a gifted student whose
gifts don't happen to fall into an academic category? Like,
lor instance, Finster Sigafoos?

Finster, a freshman at the Wyoming College of Belles
Lettres and Fingerprint Identification, has never passed a
single test; yet all who know him agree he is studded with
talent like a ham with cloves. He can, for example, sleep
standing up. He can do a perfect imitation of a scarlet tanager. (I don't mean just the bird calls; I mean he can fly
south in the winter.) He can pick up BB's with his toes. He
can say "toy boat" three times fast. He can build a rude
telephone out of 100 yards of string and two empty Personna Stainless Steel Razor Blade packages. (This last accomplishment is the one Finster is proudest of—not building
the telephone but emptying the Personna packs. To empty
a Personna pack is not easily accomplished, believe you me,
not if you're a person who likes to get full value out of his
razor blades. And full value is just what Personnas deliver.
They last and last and keep on lasting; luxury shave follows
luxury shave in numbers that make the mind boggle. Why
don't you see for yourself? Personnas are now available in
two varieties: a brand-new stainless steel injector blade for
users of injector razors—and the familiar double-edge stainless steel blade so dear to the hearth and kind to the kissers
of so many happy Americans, blades so smooth-shaving, so
long-lasting that the Personna Co. makes the following
guarantee: If you don't agree Personna gives you more luxury shaves than Beep-Beep or any other brand you might
name, Personna will buy you a pack of whatever kind you
think is better.)
But I digress. Back to Finster Sigafoos— artist, humanist,
philosopher, and freshman since 1939. Will the world ever
benefit from Finster's great gifts? Alas, no. He is in college
to stay.
But even more tragic for mankind is the ease of Clare de
Loon. Clare, a classmate of Finster's, had no talent, no
gifts, no brains, no personality. All she had was a knack for
taking tests. She would cram like mad before a test, always
get a perfect score, and then promptly forget everything
she had learned. Naturally, she graduated with highest
honors and degrees by the dozen, but the sad fact is that
she left college no more educated and no more prepared to
cope with the world than she was when she entered. Today,
a broken woman,she crouches under my sofa.

Royal Society. He will be formally inducted into Britain's oldest
scientific society at a London
ceremony in April.
Born and educated in England,
Dr. Ward attended Oxford University, Merton College and received his Ph.D. degree there in
1949. He has been engaged in
research and teaching in the
United States since 1951.
A member of the Institute of
Advanced Study at Princeton
University from 1951-'52, 1953'54 and 1960-'61 Dr. Ward has
also taught at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, the UM-

The fourth-place varsity tennis team figures to improve its
1-4 record when it crosses racquets with Washington College
tomorrow afternoon.
The netmen, under Coach Tom
McDermott, picked up their only
win to date against Western
Maryland but looked a great deal
better than they had for two
seasons.
In this 7-1 victory, top man
Joe Sorrow won 6-1, 6-0; Mark
Ellenbogen won 7-5, 6-2; Bob
Childers went 4-6,6-0,8-6; John
Lowe won 6-4, 6-4; and Rick
Jelovsek defeated his man 6-1,
6-3.
Win Doubles
Two of the Jay doubles combinations won, while the number
three doubles match was called
because of darkness.
Bob Childers put in the best
effort of the day. Losing the
first set, he lumbered back to
shut his opponent out in the second. Childers pushed on in the
tight third set, eventually taking
it 8-6.
Against Haverford on Parent's
Day, Hopkins was defeated 61/2-

Lasting close to an hour. As

with the final set at 8-8 was
declared a tie.

will seek to avenge its earlier
6-3 loss to the Greyhounds.

Polytechnic.

Frosh Batsmen Close Season;
Meet Frederick, Glen Burnie
The freshman baseball squad
ends its short season with two
home games this weekend, one
today at 3:30 against Frederick
High School, the other tomorrow
afternoon at 1:30 against Glen
Burnie High School.
The contingent brings a 1-3
record into today's encounter,
but the statistics are not a good
indication of the team's quality
and potential, according to Coach
Sam Case. Well-balanced, the
team features consistent hiters,
good fielders and excellent pitchers.
Lack Practice
"We played our first game before we had our first" practice",
commented Case. "The squad is
a good, hard-working one but
has been hurt by the weather."
This past week. for example,
practice was called off, and varsity games took up the field
on Tuesday and Thursday. Thus

the Jays had only Wednesday to
get ready for today's game.
The bulk of the hitting has
been supplied by Dave Thomas,
Webster Gray, Jim Ca111, Pete
Martindale, and Mike Shaw.
The mainstay of the pitching
staff is Erie Javel, who has
pitched 18 of the team's 30 innings so far. In one effort, he
fanned 11 batters in 6 and 2 innings. Rounding out the pitching are Rob Snyder, Dan Frey,
and Wally Siggers.
Lists Roster
The rest of Case's lineup is as
follows: Charles Allegrone, outfield; James Buchanan, first
bage; Aldrich Davis, second base;
James Easter. first base; Dave
Komocki, shortstop; Bill Mitchell,
outeld. Also listed are Tom Mobley, catcher; Ron Smith, outfield; and William Thorn, outfield.
Last season the freshman diamonders played only two games,
losing both.

go the route, even if hit hard.

By JIM MANGIARDO
With an attack that is still
hobbling and a defense which has
proven that it can do the job
when called upon, the varsity
lacrosse team travels north tomorrow to challenge an ambitious Syracuse club.
Syracuse, which usually schedules just teams from the Ohio
and New England areas, has
played the Jays only four times.
The last contest was in 1963
when Hopkins edged the visitors
10-7.
Returning from that team
which gave the Jays this battle
are Duncan Crowther, Tom Kennedy, Barry Loucks, and Art
Markusen.
Nominated All-America
Crowther is Syracuse's nomination for All-America this year.
The midfielder scored two
goals and had an assist in the
1963 game. Kennedy, another
midfielder, also had a goal in
the fray.
Completing the starting midfield for the Orangemen is
Loucks. Markusen will start on
defense. The man to watch on
the Syracuse attack is Al Smoral,
an underclassman.
"Syracuse will play the same
sort of game that Yale played,"
Coach Bob Scott predicted.
"They are hard hitting and will
do a lot of personal dogging."
Look Ahead
"It will be very easy for the
team to think ahead to Navy as
we thought of Army in the
Washington College game. But
we will have to remember that
we have to play real well to win.
We just can not lower ourselves
to their level as we have done
consistently this year against ou
minor competition."
After his brief talk about his
opposition this weekend, the
coach went on to discuss his
team's play against Army. Hopkins upset the Cadets by pouring in three goals in the final
period to break a 3-3 tie.
